text:
"Should we even care? Sure, if you’re in danger, but why stress over them? They don’t matter. We’ll laugh about this later! If I were you, I’d confuse them even more. Just imagine how embarrassed they’ll be! Forget them! We can deal with them later, but let’s enjoy this moment!" 

"Right," Raskolnikov replied. But then he wondered, what would Razumihin think tomorrow? Oddly, he hadn’t thought about it until now. As he pondered, he glanced at Razumihin. The story about Razumihin’s visit to Porfiry didn’t interest him much anymore; so much had happened since then.

In the hallway, they bumped into Luzhin. He was right on time, looking for the right room, so all three just walked in together without saying a word. The guys entered first, while Pyotr Petrovitch hung back a moment to take off his coat. Pulcheria Alexandrovna greeted him at the door, and Dounia welcomed her brother. Pyotr Petrovitch stepped in, trying to be friendly but looking a bit flustered. Pulcheria Alexandrovna seemed a bit awkward too and quickly got everyone to sit around the round table where a samovar was steaming. Dounia and Luzhin faced each other across the table, while Razumihin and Raskolnikov sat opposite Pulcheria Alexandrovna, with Razumihin next to him.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the absurdity of his situation and the reactions of those around him as they gather for a meeting.
